description.text:
In one of my latest projects for making a clone of AxiDraw (see links below) I used Arduino Uno GRBL (GRBL set to CoreXY) to drive the machine.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1796957
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1808184

When it comes to drive the Z axis the servo motors are the best choice - they are lightweight and fast compared to steppers. Unfortunately GRBL has no PWM output to control the Z axis so I decided to make a small project to convert the STEP and DIRECTION signals to proper PWM for servos. There are some similar step/direction converters projects over the net but I needed some more features like:

  • homing of the head on power up
  • end sensor for detecting when the head reached the home position
  • store the servo homing position into EEPROM and make the initial PWM to jump to this point
  • learning procedure - tell the servo where is the min and max allowed positions (restrict the servo to work in some area) and store the limits into EEPROM
  • more precise PWM timing which relies on hardware timers

After the work was done here I'm sharing the whole project - including the C sources and the HEX which are tested on real board and show excellent performance. Also added the PCB schematic, routing and Gerbers - ready to prototype it. Add a small plastic box which is 3D printed and will cover the PCB.

The learning procedure for PWM limit works but in short it is:

  1. If during power up the CAL_ENDS jumper was closed (held to GND) the firmware enters learning procedure
  2. The head moves the middle position (1.5ms pulse) and starts moving toward one of the ends (the direction of the first movement depends on the status of DIR_HOME jumper)
  3. When the rotor hits the home sensors (HOME to GND) the processor record the moment PWM as the first limit and also as home position (after power on the motor will go to this position). You can use just a single button to imitate the HOME sensor.
  4. Once end detected on step 3 the motor reverses direction and go until it hits the HOME sensor (you can use just a single button to imitate the HOME sensor). When HOME asserted the controller records the moment PWM value as the second limit.

The normal operation of the controller is:

  1. After power up it will move the head to last stored home position (from Step 3)
  2. The CNC sends step and direction signals which change the PWM and servo will move in the desired direction. One step from CNC will change the PWM pulse width with 1uS - the timings is done by hardware and is very precise.
  3. The period of the servo is 16ms, the PWM can change from 750uS to 2500uS
  4. During the CNC homing the main CNC controller may want to initiate homing on Z axis - moving Z toward the end sensors until head hits the sensors. If there are no mounted end sensors and the controller hits the PWM limits it will assert the HOME line low just like there is an end sensor and will release it one the limit is not violated.

Some characteris:

  • PWM period - 16ms
  • 1uS per step
  • active on positive edge on STEP
  • STEP speeds above 100KHz are acceptable
  • programmable upper/bottom PWM limits through learning procedure
  • detects end switches on HOME input
  • when PWM is outside the PWM limits it asserts low the HOME input (imitation of end switches), when PWM goes back in limits - HOME pin will be released.

I'll add later some more information - stay tuned.

An improved version of my original design, with a hollowed barrel, some shape improvements, and a trigger.

This project lets you create a gimbal for YOUR camera as long as it doesn't weight more than ~200g. The gimbal parameters are automatically calculated based on the size and weight of your components!

This is an OpenSCAD project for creating 2D Gimbals for Action Cams and compact cameras of different sizes and weights. I'm providing full source files, so you can customize all parts according to your specific needs.

Attach this gimbal to a selfie stick and use the battery case and the smartphone adapter from this Gimbal Grip project to power the gimbal and to control the camera.

The stl. files provided fit an Action Cam. Read the HowTo.pdf for instructions on how to create other variants! The HowTo also contains the bill of parts you need to build this.

comments.text: I have to say that this is simply an amazing project you have put together. Not only the customizable files and design documents, but the extensive time that you put into the build-guide and associated tuning information. Thank you for all the hard work!

Magnetic effector for Geeetech Rostock 301 printer.
This effector is designed around the e3d v6 lite hotend, although the effector is designed that you can mount other hotends as well.

Each end of the rods will be held by three cylindrical magnets (top one countersunk).
The groove mount for the e3d v6lite hotend can be screwed to the effector for extra stiffness.

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock 301

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60% to 80%

Notes:

Infill is not of much importance.
4 solid bottom and top layers
4 vertical shells.

BOM

You need the following materials in total:

12 pcs of cylindrical magnet 10mmx4mm
24 pcs of countersunk ring magnet 10mmx3mm
6 pc of carbon rod
12 pcs of M4 x 20mm set screw
12 pcs of steel ball for magnetic ball joint (dia: 10mm with M4 thread)

My little brother wanted something to sell at robotics tournaments, so I came up with the tools he'll need to accomplish that.

This is an openScad file to generate small pots suitable for bonsai trees or bonsai chilies.

It is possible to change base size, height and overall shape of the pot, or to generate a saucer for the pot as well.

2017-10-30 Newer version!
  • The old version is till available as bonchi-pot-old.scad
  • Added engraving option on the pot front and back
  • Sped up pot creation by avoiding minkowski (affects mainly the brim)
  • Improved drain holes to be more symmetrical and easier to print
  • Tweaked profiles a bit to be more uniform
  • Added more base shapes (cloud2, ecloud)
2016-12-30 New version
  • it is possible to define different vertical profiles as well as well as base shape
  • Variables for customizations are annotated

title: Minion Dave, cut, with gears on the inside

description.text:
I liked the remix by iClint - but the empty insides were a bit boring, so I decided to decorate them. (Even though you usally see them only for a few seconds :-D)

I'd like to make them look somehow more interesting, but adding a few gears is usually where my abilities end :-/
I tried to add in a banana in his head - it's supposed to look as if the banana screwed up his brain-gearing, I'm not sure if I succeeded. I'm afraid the 0.6 nozzle seems to be too coarse for the level of detail needed.

Notes:

Print the halves first, then measure the hole to resize the cube as needed. Default should fit, though.

Notes:

I used Gizmo Dorks PLA Clear [email protected] 210 C.
50mm/s inner/outter perimeters, 60mm/s infill, and 30mm/s for the first layer. Cooling on after the first layer.
Primed with automotive gray primer, then painted with modeling paints.

Converted original coaster from .SVG to .STL, imported into 123d Design, resized, added base, and brought to a total height of 5mm.
For the holder: Made a box 108mmx108mmx23mm and hollowed. Used half sphere to remove material on two sides to make it easier to grab coasters.

description.text:
This is a stylized Fir Cone decoration I made for my own gifting purposes: It's aimed to be printed hollow (and filled with a surprise :D) but it's also quite a torture-test for the printer in terms of bed adhesion and overhang. You may "ease" the print by scaling the z-axis separately before Slicing.

Also included a STEP-file for further tweaking. Feel free to print many, and decorate your Christmas Tree with these!

print_settings.Notes:: The CNC parts are milled on my Stepcraft 420.The machine is able to mill acrylic glass under water up to 30cm x 15cm. Three acrylic glass sheets are necessary to mill 4 * 10 digits and for smaller pieces with dots. first the digits are milled using a 45° graver, then use a 2mm milling tool to cut out the pieces.

16 M3 screws are needed to mount it.

remixed_from.author: Flashsolutions
remixed_from.title: Revised Lamp Shade for Christmas Story Leg Lamp

title: Christmas Story leg lamp remix for LED lighting

description.text:
Edit: added the tag RemixChallenge even though neither of the source items are in the challenge collection, because I put a bunch of good work into this remix, and the stuff in the challenge collection doesn't interest me. I did read the rules, unlike a bunch of the other remixes in the challenge. ;)

I printed out the Christmas story leg lamp (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:268173) with the revised shade (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:268181) for a coworker. Another coworker saw it and loved it, but wanted to convert his to have an LED light inside of it vs. just adding a tea light. I had the idea to print the leg portion with a 0% infill (hollow) so he could run wiring up through the leg, but discovered that the original lamp base has the foot intact - with toes - so that was a complication. Also, the original base was far too small for the electronics that we had planned, so I worked on the base, cutting out the hidden stuff, then stitching it back together. I modeled a new base and added that on, and was able to print it hollow.

For the shade, since we didn't need access for a tea lamp, I took the revised lamp shade, cut it in half and mirrored it. Buncha cleanup later and we have a fully intact lampshade.

Print the base in whatever color you wish, but print the shade in a transparent filament so it glows nicely.

For the assembled version, we used a 10mm high intensity diffuse gumdrop LED. Battery was a CR2032 in the base, and a switch was installed in the side. More detail photos to follow.

Update: Check out this remix by jetpuf for some nice improvements on the design, including provision for the LEDs!

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

No

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

0%

Notes:

Printed hollow for ease of running wires through the leg. Supports are necessary as the base is hollow.

At first I hoped to be able to change the centaur-part in a way to have the minion just "drop in", but the connection never looked real and the arms got in the way.

So I merged them together, smoshed the originals arms away in Meshmixer and added in the beefy arms.

The head portion is cut at an angle to make sure the eyes/goggles are printed correctly and without support.
If you find a head without neck that is wide enough, you probably can make another Centaur from it :-)

title: Realacc RX5808 Pro Split Receiver Case

description.text:
A small case for the split version of this reciever module:
http://www.banggood.com/Realacc-RX5808-Open-Source-5_8G-40CH-Split-Receiver-with-OLED-Special-for-Fatshark-Goggles-p-1068207.html

I kept it simple and small. I used ABS with 20% infill to print.
Screws: Hex m2x7,5mm from an T-Rex450kit or whatever you can find.
It fits the buzzer of 11,9/12mm diameter.
The display module is kept in place using double sided tape (on the lower stand), the diversity module can also be taped - mine hold quite good.....

There are two versions of the case for the display module:

  • soldering version (see pictures)
  • one for the video-cables to be connected using crimped servo-plugs

My cables always got loose when carrying my googles so I switched for the soldering version.

In the picture you can see another small casing. It's for my video-switch for VCR playback. I only had a pretty big 3-way-switch lying around. Maybe somebody also has a use for it, so I uploaded it too.

Happy FPV-ing!

title: Traditional bushing 8x15x24mm (LM8UU)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Traditional bushing for 8mm rods.

Summary: Don't use MoS2 grease for printed bushings, it's a fail. PTFE spray can oil works with PETG bushings if wiped dry after saturation. I have not tested silicon based or lithium based lubricants. I did look for graphite dry lubricant spray as a first choice but I did not find any in my vicinity so I chose PTFE spray can oil instead and as previously stated it seems to work if wiped dry after saturation.

My first attemp to grease the Y-axis I used MoS2 dark grey grease, it worked sufficient for the linear ball bearings. When I used MoS2 dark grey grease to my printed bushings it did not work at all, tried it with PLA-bushings and PETG-bushings, they all seemed to work at first, but after one day or less they started to get to snug on the rods, they got stuck and the stepper motor struggeled with resistanse to move. NO GO for MoS2 grease and printed bushings!

I printed a new batch of PETG bushings and tried them with sprayed PTFE oil (tens of thusands of PFTE balls per mm2, micro gap fillers), I used a threaded rod to grind the bushings to tolerance, moving the bushing back and forth along the threaded rod slowly rotating them both while applying pressure (using an 8mm drill bit might work better). Grind a while and the check the bushing against the bearing rod, grind a bit more etc. until satisfied with the tolerance. I found it to be sufficient if the bushing slides easy along the rod while dry, but sticking while wet with PTFE spray can oil. I grind the bushings until they just slide easy by them selves by gravity on the rods but sticks to the rod when saturated with PTFE oil. When satisfied with tolerance I saturated both the rods and the bushings with PTFE spray can oil, moved the bushings along the rods for a while and then thouroghly wiped them all dry with toilet paper, inside of bushings as well as whole of the rods. When saturated the bushings does not fall by gravity on the rods, they are sucked by viscosity to the rods, but when wiped clean they fall easy and fast along the rods!

Lesson1: MoS2 dark gray grease works with linear ball bearings if applied inside the bearings. The linear ball bearings runs quiet and smooth with MoS2 dark gray grease (quality of bearings may vary).
Lesson2: MoS2 grease does not work at all for printed bushings, neither PLA or PETG! At least not with fine tolerances between the rod and bushing.
Lesson3: PLA might be partially dissolved by MoS2 and refined oils, I don't know, but it could be why the smoothness feels ok the first day but not the next day. PETG are resistant to oils and greases, or so they say.
Lesson4: PTFE spray can oil works with PETG bushings if you saturate the inside of the bushings and on the rods with PTFE oil, move them back and forth rapidly by hand for a while and when done wipe them completely dry inside and out. Important to understand that if wet by oil (or grease) the bushings sticks to the rod by viscosity and boundary layer adhesion. Wipe everything dry using fresh toilet paper after saturated with PTFE spray can oil, remount and realign everything carefully and you should end up with a quiet linear PETG bushing heatbed. I did.

From my, trial and error, pratical experience.
/peen333

This is a device to mount a Microsoft lifecam HD-5000 to the eyepiece of a microscope. It includes six adjustment screws to allow for perfect alignment.   
I used springs between the CameraMountTop and CameraMountBottom so the camera can be tilted using the three adjustment screws.   
You need three 12 mm long 3mm diameter machine screws, and four 8 mm long ones, and three compression springs.  
Should fit on most microscope eyepieces... Although be warned it's a bit of a tight fit. I guess you can make the CameraMountBottom scaled up a bit to solve that issue.

author: KaptainCam

description.text: A little monster my nephew drew and then we created a little scary monster out of it.

Clarification: I am using a geared stepper with an 8mm output shaft. My hobbed gear is from Makergear and is 13mm in diameter with a 11mm diameter for the groove  (Trinity Labs website has the same size). The M4 screws are 45mm long.  
Updated 12/28/2013 - added some support for the pushfit. I had an issue with the first one's threads getting pushed out. Also, instead of cutting threads I use a hotair station to warm the plastic and then screwed the pushfit in forming the threads instead.  
I am using it with a 5.2:1 geared stepper. I modified the scad file to remove some un-needed bulk, extend the mounting feet to work on my 15mm extrusion, and add some roundness to the part. I like the idler on this model, it holds the 608 bearing nicely.

print_settings.Notes:: As this is a minimally load bearing piece a 35% triangular infill should be sufficient for normal use. The angle of the retainer end on the "no supports" version of the mount allows for printing without supports as the overhangs do not exceed 45 deg when printed wall side down. Make sure to use cooling if you do not use supports. Examples were printed with Hatchbox Black ABS @ 230C onto 110C clean glass.

title: 2 Liter Soda Bottle Opener AND Closer Wrench

description.text:
This is an extension of the first bottle opener design I submitted.  The original was designed to grip while removing the bottle cap and generally slips when trying to tighten the cap.  This new version has two rows of spines, one for removing the cap and one for tightening the cap.  I also added the option for having a handle to give you more leverage for the really stubborn bottles of fizzy.  
A couple words of warning, the handle allows you to apply enough torque to either wreck the opener spines or strip the bottle cap or both.  Second, I've noticed that some caps have a little ring around the bottom edge.  If you press the opener down over that ring then the spines won't grip.  
To eliminate the handle just compile with handle="no";  
Enjoy!
I printed this on a MakerBot Rep 2X at low resolution with 2 shells and 10% infill.  All the other settings were at default.

I added some thickness to the gaskets to seal a bit better and some ridges to the aerator body to hold them in place a bit more.
I rotate the print -30 degrees to let the aerator head sit flush with the print bed. watch out for support material clogging up the venturi port.

comments.text: I like this very much. might be a good idea to make the gasket ridges a bit higher and the gasket diameter a tad smaller to prevent the gaskets from moving and potentially dropping into the bottle.  Just a thought. :)

title: Hypercube Z carriage Remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE :
To the request of one maker I made the 15 mm diameter, named support (left - right) and clamp (left - right) -(1-2).

The z carriage bends still easily even after there first remix. I extended the legs and moved the part over the profile, just to get more room under the bed.
The bearings were in my first attempt too tight and doesn't roll fluently on the rods. I made a 16 mm room (instead of the 15 mm exact fit), with that slope i put the 2 bearings on the rod, put some hot glue in the rooms and press the Z carriage on all. With that way there is absolutely no slope and the bearings are perfectly aligned on the rod without stiking.
The bed is now much more rigid.

I give you also the CAD file (Fusion 360)

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25

Infill:

50 %

Notes:

I made it with PLA, thats strong enough for the purpose...

I printed the first parts for the right side and i think it is a design mistake that the bearing wont fit out of the box.
The screws for the lower part are not equal on each side, so you move the bearing while tightening the screws you move the bearing. So the lower bearing will not get the same direction as the upper one.
I now added some shrink tube on the upper side of the lower bearing between the bearing and the carriage and just tiding the screws again and now it moves really well.
So im going to use that one and print the other missing parts.

title: XL 7-segments Digital Clock/Thermometer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Arduino Nano + DS3231(ZS-042) + 30xAPA104-LED-Strip based digital clock/thermometer

The numbers are 195mm (7.8") height, so that one digit fits right into most Printers,
the HH:MM Version is 580mm (23") wide.

The clock is modularized, it is easy possible to just create a HH:MM:SS version configurable in the code.

There are 3 case parts: the last digit + cap(1x), a normal digit connectable to the next right(3x or 5x), and a dot-case(1 or 2x).
Additionaly are 4 types diffusor-inlets: A (top/bottom), B (upleft/downright), C(upright/downleft) and D(center) and one for the dots.
The last digit case contains space for the two boards (Arduino Nano and ZS-042)
As strip can be used all WS2811, APA104 or Neopixel kinds. I would prefer the 3-wire solutions, since soldering 30(or 46) interlinks is awefull lot of work.

The digit cases can be screwed against a large beam with M3 screws directly driven in the back to give everything a better strength.

Wiring Instructions:

  1. Internally the line in the digits follow the pattern:
    -2-
    1 3
    -0-
    6 4
    -5-
    so just connecting the arduino gnd, +5V and DI of the beginning of the strip and go from 0 in the smallest (far right) digit up through the whole clock. Just 3 wires through all the digits in the number.
    Hint: soldering the ~6cm bridges between all 7 digits of a number, add a longer triple to the end, fiddling the wires through the holes, solder them together and finally stick the led-strip-parts inside the gaps in the cases.

  2. Connect the SDA, SCL, Gnd and Vcc of the ZS-042 to Arduino pins A4, A5, gnd and 3.3V Get rid of the diode right of the DS3231 (the black/red cylinder) to avoid try to load the CR2032 (which is a stupid idea, don't know why they ship that stupid combination of battery and laoding circuit?!? Also i removed the pin-header)
    Connect the gnd and 5V of the usb-A-cable (red and black) or to the power supply. There is a hole underneath the arduino to lead the wire to the back.

  3. Fiddle the photodiode into the hole in the cap. Connect the photodiode to vcc(5V) and Analog-Pin A0, and a suitable resistor from pin A0 to ground. Check the analog-value readout e.g. in a small test-program for the brightest and darkest planned environment (just cover the diode) and enter it in the configuration section or just see if the default settings work for you.

  4. Test everything. If it works you can slide both boards in special gaps at the end-number case. Don't solder pin-headers to the nano. I was not planning to reuse the nano either, since it is part of the clock.

Software will be uploaded later (since printing everything will take a week, I'm a little in advance to anybody here, but don't be afraid, it will come next week (this is a cristmas gift ;) so it must work, its nearly done )

Features (can be configured in the code)

  • different colors depending on time of day
  • automatic brightness adjustments
  • automatic summer/wintertime setting
  • automatic toggling between HH:MM, MM:SS and TT.T°
  • time / date is set via serial terminal
  • temperature readout via the DS3231 (shown in °C, if you need °F ask and I add a configuration)
  • ?? any other ideas - ask in the comments

BOM: (everything including Print Material: ~15-20€/$)

  • 1x Arduino Nano,
  • 1x DS 3231 (case fit for a ZS-042 board)
  • 1x 1m APA104/WS28** 30LED/m LED-Strip (or .5m of 60LEDs/m)
    (one can use 1m of 60LEDs/m to use a pair for each digit to make a brighter one)
    (= 30x or 44x for the HH:MM:SS version)
  • ~ 200g colored filament for the frame (it should be optically dense) for 3x digit-case, 1x end-case and one dot-case
  • ~150g white filament for 7 inlets each number (there are kind of different white filaments around, I choose one that is a little less dense, let more light shine through but still hides the dot of the LEDs, transparent filaments let lights through but don't diffuse the light alot)
  • 1x aluminium bar 55cm (L or U-shaped) to strengthen the back
  • 8x M3x10-M3x20 (the holes in STL are 3mm, but my prints are offering me then a hole where M3 screws cutting into the plastic)
  • ~ 6m >AWG26 wires, 3 colors would help
  • 1x photoresistor and suitable resistor (in the range of the mean-value of the photoresistor) for brightness measurement, normally about 10K)
    either:
  • 1x USB-A-Cable, directly soldered to the 5V and gnd of the nano
  • 1x USB-power adapter
    or:
  • 5V ~1A power adapter and a connection plug to the nano

Remarks

  1. The used white diffusors makes it hard to read in a bright environment. either use transparent filament wich is not work well as a diffusor or use the 60LED/m version and use 2 led's per digit-bar. (minor changes to code, just uncomment something in the configuration section)
  2. Setting the clock needs a serial terminal, the DS3231 is stable enough, so that one does not need a button

Printer:

Dark i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.4mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

All parts are designed to be printed with a 0.4 nozzle, so that the case parts are sliced to a doule sided shell, and the inner diffusors just a single white wall. Since the diffusor front is only .5mm thick, two layers create them and there is noch infill pattern visible.

description.text:
12/18/16 - I will be adding files in correct sizes for other size kong plugs soon.

These are for plugging the ends of the holes in the ends of the Medium http://amzn.to/2hJ5cGR & Large http://amzn.to/2hynWuY Kong Classic Dog Toys. The small end is pretty tight on the medium but works fine it you give it some lube with some olive oil.

We like to fill the kong toys with our own home made treats then FREEZE the kong toy for our dogs to enjoy. The plugs allow us to fill the kong and hold the fluid in while we freeze them in the freezer.

chicken or beef stock http://amzn.to/2gZui5V
plain water
Pumpkin http://amzn.to/2i3FITQ

these are an easy print, they are designed to fit tight so that they wont leak in the freezer, if you are having trouble putting them in, put a dab of veggi oil or butter around the plug and it should pop in.

description.text:
The Marble Puzzle (a short lesson in physics)

It is fun to dig into history and find out with what kids were playing in the pre-battery age.
The idea of this puzzle is to maneuver the two marbles into their own homes left and right at the end of the slope. However, due to the angles involved, it is impossible to achieve this by just tilting the unit. The only way to solve the puzzle is to apply forces on both marbles in the direction of their homes. Tilting works fine for the first marble. The second one is more difficult. Think of how a centrifuge works...twist it! (don't tell anybody)
If you have larger or smaller marbles, just scale it up or down.
Search Thingiverse for “willemvd” to find more pre-battery age kid stuff.

author: lkvapil

description.text:
We gave my mother-in-law money for a new couch for Christmas so I designed a couch box to put the money in.
It is a long print

Stereo photography
A simple way to make low cost stereo picture pairs is combining two digital compact cameras with a distance between the lenses of about 6,5 cm, which is the average distance between human eyes. When using two compact cameras, the distance between the lenses is mostly over 6,5 cm. However, a larger distance enhances the three dimensional effect. So we can live with it. The two shutters are activated simultaneously, synchronized by adjustable M3 screws. To be able to use a tripod, a nut with camera thread is added. You can get one at the photo shop around the corner. The viewing angle of the cameras cannot be adjusted to obtain a stable unit and improve shutter synchronization. In close up, the effective photo size gets smaller. The shutter release strips are connected. An opening in the strips allows switching on/off without taking the cameras out of the holder. After removing the spacer, the cameras can be taken out easily to set menu and mode. Slip them back into their housings and you are ready to go.
Watching stereo pictures:

  • Use an iPhone in combination with VR-glasses.
  • Print them with the left picture at the left and the right picture at the right and look at them with a stereo viewer.
  • Print them with the left picture at the right and the right picture at the left, cross your eyes and look at the middle picture (see attached rabbit 3D-photograph). If you don't see the 3D picture, slowly move one ear to the shoulder.
    This thing is designed for two really cheap and not so good digital cameras (crossed eyes pond picture). However, even when the quality is very poor, an interesting 3D effect is present (printed animals).

Since the OpenSCAD design files are included, this Thing can be adapted to different compact camera models.

title: Tiny Tie - The FPV Tie Racer

description.text:
The Tiny Tie is inspired by the Tiny Whoop and Inductrix and of course the iconic Tie Fighter. Rather than a replica of the Tie Fighter, the Tiny Tie is designed as a customizable performance indoor first person view (FPV) Tie Racer platform with flight characteristics comparable to the Inductrix or Tiny Whoop, so they can race side by side. With FPV you can fly the drone while watching the video feed from the onboard camera in near real-time - really feels like you're piloting the drone. The Tiny Tie is also very durable and tolerates more than one would expect. The wings act as landing gear and protect the props against most impacts.

You can see a video of it in action here: https://youtu.be/cZUhjEQbCC8

Flight Controller: I tested this design with both the BeeCore and BeeBrain flight controller, both performed excellent. I am providing links to Amazon.com but you can buy them directly or via local hobby store.

BeeCore: http://a.co/h5HKdyE

BeeBrain: http://a.co/g3GPaDE

Propellers: You need 4 Blade/Inductrix/Tiny Whoop propellers, 2 CW and 2 CCW rotating. There are many other choices of colours and sets, you can find one set here: http://a.co/3gWA819

Motors: The Tiny Tie requires 4 of 6x15mm coreless brushed motors, 2 that rotate CW and 2 that rotate CCW such as these: http://a.co/2PO5gWW

Camera: Although the Tiny Tie can be built without FPV support and its flight performance is even better in such a case, it's really much more fun when you fly with FPV. To implement FPV, you will need a FPV compatible 5.8GHz camera and transmitter such as the following but there are many options: http://a.co/bhn83p6

To mount the camera on the flight controller you will need the appropriate camera mount. I included the STL for the camera mount I designed for the camera shown but you can find other custom mounts for different cameras on thingiverse.

FPV Goggles: To operate in FPV mode, you need FPV googles that will receive the 5.8GHz video signal and display the video. There are many choices, I personally use the FatShark V3 goggles: http://www.fatshark.com/

Radio: Of course you also need a radio. There are many options as well, I use a Spektrum DX9: http://www.spektrumrc.com/Products/Default.aspx?ProdId=SPMR9900

comments.text: Thanks for this awesome design! I just had one printed up today in PETG. The whole frame came out to about 6.2g. Using the stock fc on some 17k motors I was getting a lot of oscillations. I tried using rubber grommets to mount the fc, new pigtail, and new Tattu packs. Still had oscillations. It seems like the cause is due to the vibrations of the arms twisting when throttled. I was too lazy to swap my BeeBrain to see if the fc made a difference but I did glue my McKune carbon stiffener to the arms and it stopped the shaking. Maybe PLA is stiffer, I'm not sure. Also the motors tend to tilt towards where the slit in the mount is. A slit on the opposite of the mount may allow for the motors to sit perfectly straight.
comments.author: Von_Erick

comments.text: I think PETG has a considerably lower modulus than PLA so it may flex more. In some cases oscillations can also arise from non-optimal PID settings in the FC, but given you were able to resolve it be stiffening the arms suggests it was related to arm stiffness. Do you have PLA to try and compare? I tried the opposing slit and it significantly reduces the holding strength of the mounts but I'll think about it.  What is the total weight without battery?
comments.author: Von_Erick

comments.text: This is my LOS rig so no FPV cam. It comes in at 18.1g wo/ lipo and 19.0g with the stiffener. I just ordered the square shaped carbon stiffener on eBay so I can have it on without getting in the way of the battery. My printer guy has PLA and a few other filaments I may have him print out. I'll report back when I get them printed and tested!

comments.text: Will this work with PLA or will I need TPU or TPE for the motor mounts etc.?
comments.author: Dravenb4u

comments.text: Actually, I have only printed frames with PLA (made many) and also tried it a couple times with the Formlabs Tough resin and in both cases the frames printed out great and were functional. Depending on the printing result you may have to immobilize the motors in their mounts with a thin tear of masking or other conformal tape around the circumference. If the motors get really hot, this piece of tape will also help. I considered making more robust mounts but the additional weight was not worth it and in most of my attempts these immobilized the motors very effectively without any tape.

title: Flying Glider  Hangable Cards
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Print these great flying mini F44 jet and T22 club gliders as gifts, decorations, or cards!

Use a thin (2mm cross section works well) rubber band on the included launcher and adjust for loops, daring zooms, and long flights.

The fast, zoomy F44 is best flown outdoors in a park sized area, as flights may be quite long.

T22 is a docile, floaty flyer that can easily be hand launched and can be flown in smaller spaces and yards, or even hand launched indoors in a large room.

Fun for kids or the young at heart...these are the gliders I wish I could have bought when I was a kid!

Includes ornament card sets and an F44 with integral canopy for easier assembly.

Check out some of my other printable planes here at Thingiverse, and check out my other freebies and premium gliders at threedsy.com!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Orient print so that first layer infill is wingtip to wingtip, not front and back.

Optional for multicolor on single color printer, as shown in pictures: pause and change filament at 0.45mm

Also can be printed at 0.2mm if scaled up to 1.333x for a bigger glider!

The f44 can be printed on a 100mm or larger bed, the T22 requires about 125mm.

Description: A high performance glider ideal for looping flights and long glides.

Plastic: ABS

Layers: .15mm

Fill: 30%

Perimeters: 2

Solid Layers: 2

Orientation:
first layer spanwise wingtip to wingtip, altrenate by 90 degrees. A 45 degree (or non right angle) axis will cause asymetrical wing warping under load (bad).

Build Notes:
Allow to cool before carefully removing from build platform. The wings are easily deformed during removal, and must be absoultely symmetrical for proper flight. Removal with a very thin plastic spatula (print one!) is preferred. Test fit and trim if necesary prior to final assembly with a very small amount of CA Glue.

Flight Notes:
The F series are roll sensitive due to their low aspect ratio wings.

Launching is by hand or with a 1/16" x 8" (2mm) rubber band. Rubber band launch is reccomended for best results. (the micro F47 requires a much smaller band) A band that is too short will cause the glider to strike the launcher or your hand.

Test and adjust by hand launching first. Some of the models are difficult to hand lauch and should be tested with a 1/16" rubber band instead.

A slight elevator - up reflex is required for flight. This is accomplished by latching the elevons up on the relex tabs on the aft end of the fuselage. these tabs may be adjusted by filing to achieve desired flight characteristics. After the desired flight profile is attained, a tiny drop of glue will prevent the elevons from moving from their latched position.

To correct turning or spiraling, differential elevator control (elevon) is preferred, though some aileron bending may be needed if the wings are warped from improper bed removal. Carefully bend this in with finger pressure, but avoid creasing or excessive strain.

A gradual test/adjust cycle is recommended.

Print these great flying mini F44 jet and T22 club gliders as gifts, decorations, or cards!

Use a thin (2mm cross section works well) rubber band on the included launcher and adjust for loops, daring zooms, and long flights.

The fast, zoomy F44 is best flown outdoors in a park sized area, as flights may be quite long.

T22 is a docile, floaty flyer that can easily be hand launched and can be flown in smaller spaces and yards, or even hand launched indoors in a large room.

Fun for kids or the young at heart...these are the gliders I wish I could have bought when I was a kid!

Includes ornament card sets and an F44 with integral canopy for easier assembly.

Check out some of my other printable planes here at Thingiverse, and check out my other freebies and premium gliders at threedsy.com!

title: eLeaf iStick TC40W 18650 battery replacement extension

description.text:
If your TC40W's battery dies, you'll want to try to replace it.
After cautiously opening the iStick case, you'll see a soldered LiIon battery and think as I did "Easy job: it's a 18650!"... Well, not so easy, because the original battery is not a 18650 (18mm x 65mm), but a 20600 (20mm x 60mm). So even if the 18650 diameter would be OK, there is not enough room in the length of the case for a 18650.
So, I designed this small extension that sits between the top plate (where the atomizer is fitted) and the main body of the TC40W.

After printing this, you'll have to:

  • Change the two wires that connect the atomizer connector to the main PCB for longer ones: Use thick enough cables, if possible with silicone sheathing.
  • Sand the interior of the screw tubes of the printed part as there are small bumps there on the interior of the top plate (see picture)
  • Replace the two top plate screws by longer ones

I printed mine in PLA as I never go over 15W and the plate doesn't heat. If that's not your case, use PETG.

A word of caution:
When disassembling or assembling your TC40W be VERY CAREFUL not to short anything as a 20600 or 18650 lithium battery is a dangerous device. I'm not responsible for anything happening to you, your house or the earth if you try this...

Printer:

CTC Bizer Dual Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%
You'll have to sand or cut a small piece of the interior part of the screw tubes of the printed device to accommodate the small bumps in the interior of the TC40W's top plate

description.text: Its a Minecraft jungle tree.  Like, follow and comment for more! Also, comment on what you think i should make next!

Gcode file

The gcode file already has the extruder temperature adjusted, with the profile of my Malyan M150 printer (similar to Wanhao Duplicator i3, sharing profile with Pusa i3).

Customizer

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=915435

Extruder temperature adjustment

If you slice the STL file, remember to adjust the temperature by editing the gcode file, or using the postprocessing command TweakAtZ in Cura. Start extruder temp at 260 ºC, reduce temp at 13 mm (3 mm base plus 10 mm block) to 255 ºC, and then every 10 mm reduce by 5 ºC.

remixed_from.title: Sailor Moon Crescent Moon Healing Wand for cosplay

title: Sailor moon Moonstick with touch switch

description.text:
I designed a rod to go along with the wand head. It's got 4 holes on the side through which a set of wires can be run. When you touch both exposed wires, the crystal on top slowly brightens to full. When you release it, it dims out gradually. The speed of the lighting changes depending on the conductivity of your skin. So if your hands are really dry, you might have to wait a little while before you see it light.

I uploaded the shaft as a single piece and as two interlocking pieces in case you don't have the height in the build area. For whatever reason, the top half of the shaft isn't displaying right. If you're having trouble downloading it, shoot me a PM and I'll send it to you some other way.

Also, I redid the crystal to allow for more space inside to fit the LEDs. No infill there as it will mess up the light dispersion.

You can see it in action here
https://youtu.be/jnn7GgUZwss

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

.1

15%

Notes:

Make sure that no supports are placed in the wire holes or the interior of the crystal because they're hard to get out and unnecessary.

author: kak93

description.text:
This a belt clip for the Topeak Ratchet Rocket, specifically with the plastic case: https://www.amazon.com/Topeak-Ratchet-Rocket/dp/B01GS9ADF8

This is a CNC/machining/metal CAD. The holes will not be dimensionally correct through 3D printing due to shrinkage, & probably all the holes will be too tight. I won't make a 3D printing specific CAD unless I get explicit interest therefor.

I rendered this in aluminum a few years ago with a Tormach 1100 CNC, & it was kind of heavy. I carried it extensively for about a year. A few photos of that are available. I lost the CAD, so I made another one. I pulled all the measurement off of the existing piece. I added a huge slot in the middle to reduce weight & unnecessary material.

18 Dec 2016: Added another version, _2, which has even more weight/redundancy reduction.

21 Dec 2016: Forgot to mention, I think this fits an 1.5" wide belt.

You will need the two countersunk 2 mm bolts that come with it. Just place it on the case, drop the bolts through, & tighten.

You may need to do some filing to get the corner/fillets to fit.

author: zuspiel

description.text: I was playing with sprockets and chain for driving L3-G0's motors (http://L3-G0.blogspot.com - My full size Lego R2D2, video on Youtube). Having difficulty finding a sprocket supplier, I decided to print some, but I wasn't able to find an OpenSCAD type sprocket library. This "knows" about many types of ANSI chain, Motorcycle Chain, and maybe Bicycle chain, but I've only tested with ANSI #25 roller chain because that's what L3-G0 uses. Sizes are: #25, #35, #40, #41, #50, #60 & #80 roller chain, and 420, 425, 428, 520, 525, 530 & 630 motorcycle chain. You can comment if the other sizes work for you (& if you had to tweak the fudges). L3-G0's complete now, so check out his blog & share with friends. Also please give a thumbs up on his video channel!

Though I included a couple .stl files, Sprockets is intended for you make your own size sprocket using OpenSCAD. It's fairly easy to do your own thing, and if you forget, there're comments in the sprockets.scad file. Skip the first steps if you've played with OpenSCAD and know how libraries behave.
  • Get OpenSCAD if you don't have it already, http://www.openscad.org/
  • Copy sprockets.scad to some folder on your machine.
  • Either use a real library location, or to KISS, just make a new document and save it in the same folder as sprockets.scad.
  • Enter something like this into your OpenSCAD script (on the left)
    use <sprockets.scad>
    // #25 chain, 9 tooth, sprocket with 5/16" bore.
    sprocket(25, 9, 5/16);
  • Press F5 (Design->Compile). You'll see a sprocket with 9 teeth for #25 chain
  • To make OpenSCAD create an STL file, you have to render it first, press F6 (Design->Compile and Render)
  • Design->Export the STL.
    • You may want to play with some of the fudge factors for your printer, or maybe for other chain sizes. The values I have hard-coded seem to work with my #25 chain, and replicator 1. Sprockets.scad also seems to use a large # of elements. For 22 teeth, you'll probably have to bump up the preference for turn off rendering # of elements. sprocket() takes a few parameters. First one is roller chain size, then # of teeth, then bore size (in inches). You can also add a hub // size: ANSI Roller Chain Standard Sizes, default 25,
    // or motorcycle sizes,
    // or 1 for bike w/derailleur or 2 for bike w/o derailleur
    // teeth: Number of teeth on the sprocket, default 9
    // bore: Bore diameter, inches (Chain sizes seem to favor inches), default 5/16
    // hub_diameter: Hub diameter, inches, default 0
    // hub_height: Hub height TOTAL, default 0. So, for an example with a hub look at Sprockets15_Hub.scad: use <sprockets.scad>
    sprocket(25, 15, 1/4, 3/4, 1/4); That's #25 chain, 15 tooth, 1/4" bore, 3/4" hub, 1/4" from the plate. There's a mm2inches(mm) function if you want to use mm instead:
    // 608 bearings are 7mm wide, 8mm ID and 22mm OD
    // Make a hub big enough for a 608 bearing
    use <sprockets.scad>
    bore=mm2inches(22);
    hubwidth=mm2inches(30);
    hubheight=mm2inches(7)-get_thickness(25);
    sprocket(25, 19, bore, hubwidth, hubheight); When openscad renders it, some info gets echo'd too. Add the "Thickness" to your hub height to get total thickness of the part. ECHO: "Pitch=", 0.25
    ECHO: "Pitch mm=", 6.35
    ECHO: "Roller=", 0.065
    ECHO: "Roller mm=", 1.651
    ECHO: "Thickness=", 0.11
    ECHO: "Thickness mm=", 2.794
    ECHO: "Outside diameter=", 1.32616
    ECHO: "Outside diameter mm=", 33.6844
    ECHO: "Pitch Diameter=", 1.20243
    ECHO: "Pitch Diameter mm=", 30.5418 The "fudge factors" I have built in, in case your parts are too tight follow. I'd try running the part back & forth in the chain a few times before tweaking these, just to rub off printing irregularities. If your bores are too tight, you might try this. 0 works for me though, a bit stiff getting on a 5/16 rod with a 5/16 bore, but it fits with minimal wiggling. If not, bump this up (or down).
    FUDGE_BORE=0; // mm to fudge the edges of the bore If the rollers are stuck in the channels, try adjusting this. For my chain & printer, 0 seems to be fine. This is the bottom part of where the chain sits.
    FUDGE_ROLLER=0; // mm to fudge the hole for the rollers More likely, the printer doesn't want to print the tips of the teeth very round, at least I seem to have quite a bit of error here. This fudge factor decreases the diameter of the circle used to round the teeth. My printer seems to make them rather squarer than the image in OpenScad.
    FUDGE_TEETH=1; // Additional rounding of the teeth (0 is theoretical, my rep 1 seems to need 1 on medium.) Additionally, typically sprocket teeth are chopped off. If you want to keep the teeth, or use slightly different math for the distance they stick out, look at the lines following this comment:
    // Trim outer points
    Comment out all 3 lines to keep the teeth, or change to the other cylinder to have slightly shorter teeth, or do your own thing. There're 3 functions that return some info about chain sizes:
    get_pitch(size) returns the pitch of the chain in inches
    get_roller_diameter(size) returns the roller diameter
    get_thickness(size) returns the thickness of the sprocket (excluding any hub) And don't forget to visit L3-G0 the Lego R2-D2's blog or Youtube channel. The gears I'm building are intended for his motorized feet....

comments.text: I've successfully printed various #40 and #35 chain and tested them in a couple of different assemblies. Reducing the thickness of each in the table by about a thousandth of an inch (0.001) or 0.0254mm delivers enough tolerance for the chain to move freely over the sprocket teeth. I've also added 06B (British standard) chain to my tables as I have quite a bit of this chain and wanted to use it.

comments.text: There're some variables in the scad that fudge some of the parameters, you might try tweaking those (FUDGE_TEETH is more likely, or FUDGE_ROLLER?). I used #25 chain for L3-G0 (http://L3-G0.com) it was a bit tight.
comments.author: gadgetaddict

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. I'll have a play with those settings this weekend and let you know how it goes. I'll also hit this one with my files and see how much difference that makes first. The original version exported from openscad was much fatter but I made it thinner in sketchup. Thanks again!
comments.author: kresty

comments.text: Ack.  If you had to make it skinnier, maybe I messed up the measurements?  As I said, I only used smaller chain, so the rest of the numbers are copied from some table somewhere and not tested.  Let us know how it goes.
comments.author: gadgetaddict

comments.text: Thanks! This is precisely what I was looking for. Just yesterday I installed OpenSCAD and I'm still not very sure how to visualize the pieces I have in mind. I will have a look at the code, I'm sure I will learn something :)
comments.author: Makerto

comments.text: Hope it helps.  Note that at my printer's resolution, what I end up with isn't exactly what I put in, so I had to wear these in & stuff.  Depending on the project you may need different "fudge" factors.
comments.author: Makerto

description.text:
This is a blower for a Chimera upgrade installed on Robo 3D, it works amazing for me.
The two regular fans were too weak for me so I decided to install these blowers on my printers, they are relatively inexpensive on ebay.
I attached a .step file in case you wanted to make any changes to it.
Thanks to Mike Kelly for making .step files of carriage and chimera available and making it a lot easier to work on the shroud.
The hardware required are (5) 6/32 screws and the fan itself, one fan is more than enough, so I don't think if I will consider making one for the other side.

I will be working on one for E3D V6 soon, hopefully it will be possible.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

150-200

Infill:

30

Notes:

I printed parts using PLA at around 45mm/s, with a brim for the shroud to increase adhesion.
The first shroud I printed was printed using Mike's shrouds and I re-printed it using a new shroud for better quality.

I downloaded Mike Kelly's .step files of Chimera carriage and I built the shroud around it.
Mike's files are available @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:671881

title: Probe Holder for Uni-T UT61E
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I love my UNI-T UT61E meter except... it doesn't have any probe holders. I made this part to address that problem. It does have a screw to mount your meter to the wall or work bench if have the need. After this simple 3D print, I'm in love with my meter again. Maybe this "thingi" will help others restore their love too.

The fit for the probes is a bit tight. It may take a while before the probes will sit in all the way. For me, the probes hold well enough even though they aren't seated all the way in. I put a blue rubber band in the front from one side to the other to ensure the probe holder doesn't come off the meter but this isn't absolutely necessary. It holds either way.

Did I forget to say I "LOVE" this meter? It's a great meter at a fantastic price.

title: Dice Tower and Case (Plinko Style)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note: I never printed/tested this. See the note below for an explanation. For my newer design that I did print, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2060892

A plinko style dice tower. It includes a case that can store dice and pencils when it's not in use. When it's time to play, the case becomes the dice tray.

It's designed to use 1/4" plexiglass in the front because it's more fun if you can see the dice rolling. The actual thickness of the plexiglass I used is 0.222". Find the piece I used here: http://a.co/b3aKqLg.

I've included an stl for the front. This can be used as the front piece or as a guide to cut your plexiglass.

Note:
I designed this before I got my 3d printer. It's an adaptation/update of a dice tower I designed and made out of wood. After getting a few prints under my belt, I realized that 3d printing required a different design approach than woodworking. I scrapped this design and started over. Well, just in case some people prefer this design, I decided to publish it anyway. My newer, preferred design is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:206089 The new one has an open front, it does not require assembly or plexiglass, it includes an organizer for use during play, and it's easy to print with no supports

title: "KillaJoule" cookie cutter - the world's fastest electric motorcycle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The "KillaJoule" electric sidecar streamliner motorcycle is built by Eva Håkansson and Bill Dubé and is the world's fastest electric motorcycle (270 mph/ 400.2 kph as of August 2016). If you love motorcycles and/or electric vehicles, you can now make your own KillaJoule cookies!

The cookie cutter comes in two varieties: with imprint and without imprint. Which you prefer is all about your personal preference. There are also cutters for the sidecar platform and sidecar wheel so you can make it a 3D dimensional cookie, if you like.

The cookie cutters are designed in Autodesk Inventor, and printed from Polymaker Polylite PLA in the color "True Red" on a LulzBot TAZ 5.

You can find my grandmother's recipe for the gingerbread cookies here: http://media.evahakansson.com/2016/11/Grandma_Carlas_gingerbread_cookies_Nov_2016.pdf

title: Flexistruder BSP28 ready (Body only)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
English:
I made a little change to the FlexiStruder by MikeFrancies, published Oct 29, 2015 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1099016). The flexistruder seemed to be the best solution, for printing flexible filaments. I run a similar extrudermod on my "German RepRap NEO", and now I am upgrading my Anet A8 (Prusa i3 - clone). I printed the flexistruder and realized, that there is no chance to get one of my pushfits attached. The flexistruder needed a little bit mor "flesh" around the output, to take a BSP28 (1/8") thread. So I imported the stl into Sketchup, stretched it a bit around the output and widened the hole to ~9mm. Now you can easily cut the thread and attach the pushfit. If you want to push the Bowden through those normal pushfits till it reaches barely the bearing and the hobbed bolt, you have to drill the pushfit carefully to 4mm. Don't drill too deep, if your drill touched the claws of the pushfit, the pushfit won't work anymore.

YOU WILL NEED THE LEVER FROM THE ORIGINAL THING: http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1727116
*Just added the lever here

Deutsch:
Ich habe den FlexiStruder by MikeFrancies, published Oct 29, 2015 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1099016) etwas verändert. Der Flexistruder sah für mich aus wie die optimale Lösung um flexibles Filament auf meinem neuen Anet A8, den ich auf Bowden umrüste zu drucken. Eine ähnliche Mod nutze ich schon seit einiger Zeit an meinem German RepRap NEO. Ich hab den Flexistruder gedruckt und erst dann gemerkt, dass ich keines meiner Pushfits montieren kann. Die Pushfits, die ich noch da hatte, haben alle ein 1/8" Gewinde (BSP28). Um das in den Flexistruder zu schneiden, braucht er etwas mehr "Fleisch" um das Ausgangsloch. Ich hab die STL dann in Sketchup importiert und an den entsprechenden Stellen etwas geändert. Das Ausgangsloch hab ich auch auf ~9mm erweitert, so dass man ein BDP28 Gewinde direkt rein schneiden kann. Wenn man den Bowden fast bis zum Kugellager und dem Förderrad durchstecken will, muss man das Pushfit auf der Gewindeseite noch vorsichtig auf 4mm aufbohren. Man darf aber auf keinen Fall so tief bohren, dass man an die Klammern des Pushfits kommt, denn dann ist das Pushfit kaputt.

MAN BRAUCHT NOCH DEN HEBEL DES ORIGINALEN FLEXISTRUDERS: http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1727116
*Ich habe den Hebel hier einfügen dürfen

title: Mini Gun with Rainbow Loom Bands

description.text:
Mini gun designed for rainbow loom bands.

Gun will hold about 84 rounds. There are 12 posts on the barrel, and I can stack 7 bands on each post.

One of each stl part will be required.

Wrap some dental floss in the bands as you load them on.

Besides the printed parts, you will need:
Schedule 40 1" PVC pipe that is 4" long. Ends should be cut square as possible.
1/4" ready rod cut to length as needed(~6").
3x 1/4" nuts (7/16" across flats).
BBs for ball bearings(0.177"/4.5mm diameter).
Bamboo skewers, cut 6x 3-3/4" long. You may need to sand down the ends to fit.
3'-4' of dental floss.
A few drops of vegetable oil to lubricate bearings.

Clean up bearing races for smoother operation.
The cap may need to be sanded down for extra clearance. I also needed to scale the cap on the X and Y axis by 1.03 to make the threads fit when printing at 0.25mm/layer.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are printed using PVA.

description.text:
From time to time and for various reasons, I revisit older designs. This thing, the PLA / PVA Spring Motor Demonstrator, is a revisit and redesign of my original PLA Spring Motor Demonstrator here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402412.

Yes, the redesigned version is smaller, and is only printed in one color, however, the most important feature is that it was printed in place and fully assembled, using PLA for the structure and water soluble PVA for supports. When printing is complete, just throw it into a water bath for a few hours and it's ready to run, no assembly required!

While I had heard of dual extrusion printers before, I had never heard of PVA until I saw the release of the Ultimaker 3 (I must lead a "sheltered" 3D printing life...). After many discussions with the wife, and the onset of Christmas, I received an Ultimaker 3 Extended which included the PVA filament. I am not a fan of PLA "supports" as they tend to leave a rough surface at the point of contact with the component being printed. However, the Cura slicer and Ultimaker have solved this with the use of PVA supports, as the point of contact surfaces are remarkably smooth leaving no visual hint that support was used.

The first photograph shows from left to right, the original PLA Spring Motor Demonstrator, the redesigned PLA / PVA Spring Motor Demonstrator encased in PVA, and the PLA / PVA Spring Motor Demonstrator after it's water bath.

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6w0yKowwVEk.

Video of prototype in the water bath is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jeWeDsPPoC8. Note I'm using a printed circuit board etching tank with a bubbler and heater to expedite the PVA dissolve.

Designed using Fusion 360, sliced using Cura, and printed in PLA / PVA on an Ultimaker 3 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Supports are printed using PVA.

After printing, place the assembly in a water bath. After a few hours (depending on the water temperature, agitation, etc.), remove the assembly and carefully attempt to rotate the gears. If they do not rotate, return the assembly to the water bath for another few hours then try again. If they do rotate, rotate the gears enough to expose the PVA trapped between the gears, the return to the water bath. Repeat until all PVA is removed. Also, changing the water frequently will assist in expediting the PVA dissolve process.

Finally, I posted a video showing the water bath I used; a printed circuit board etching tank with an air agitator and heater. The agitator generates bubbles that better penetrate the tight areas between the gears, supports, etc., that assist in dissolving the PVA. I run the tank heater at 28 degrees celsius (approximately 82.4 degrees centigrade) which also assists in dissolving the PVA.
Designed using Fusion 360.

description.text:
This is a dust filter and filament oiler for the Replicator 2X as well as the Replicator 2 with updated extrusion head. Works well for solving printing issues with Rep 2X when printing with PLA. The original suggested solution is to print thing #153807 and put oil on the sponge. This is a low profile dual chambered version of the idea with oil in the sponge in upper chamber and dry sponge in lower chamber to catch any excess. Only a thin film of oil is needed, less is more in this case. Front door is snap-fit for easy cleaning and re-loading of oil.  
Update: Minor tweaks to the locking lips and the lid to allow more precise fitting and minimal post-print clean-up

Left and right handed versions are included for dual extrusion. 0.2mm or lower slice thickness is recommended. 3 shells and 50% in-fill. It is better to print the body and cover separately; body benefits from raft and support, lid is best printed directly on the bed.  
Update: minor tweaks to the body and lid files to allow more precise mating. When printed on the Rep2X, only the lid edges that fit under the locking tabs need to be sanded down about 0.2mm and the rest just snaps right in.

title: removable load for PIKO coal cars

description.text:
I saw removable coal loads for my freight cars in hobby store and i decided to do my own.

Fits PIKO Eas and Eas-x 4 axle coal cars, tested with model numbers: 96051, 96013-2, 58725
Dimensions of insert 140x29.5x17mm

Printer:

DIY based on prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

10%

To get what i have:

  1. prepare what you want to load into your car
    I used coal because i wanted to model coal loads that are used around my place.
    In case of coal its better to avoid powdered coal because it glues badly and looks unnatural, at least for me.
    I got myself a lump of coal and hammered it down to 1-2mm chunks.
  2. either use colored filament or paint top of your 3d printed insert with color that matches your load. I used spray black paint.
  3. put your load onto an insert so it looks nice and glue it down with diluted wood glue in the same way as you would be ballasting tracks
  4. wait till glue sets, for me it was about 12hrs
  5. profit!

comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: I do both.  Some things are simple enough that redesigning them from scratch is the best option.  I recreate a lot of things in Sketchup, especially if they are simple.  The Z-axis dust covers, I had created 4 to 5 months ago and am only now posting them on Thingiverse.  I see you published your own version.  Back 4 months ago, no one had anything to copy from, at least not in the Anet community.  Other things, I borrow from, such as NickRimmer's fan duct contribution.  I then modify them because they need adaption or could stand improvement.  Some things I customize to suit my personal liking or need, such as the C270 camera mount.  I imported the original STL file into Sketchup and then stretched the dimensions, adjusted the screw holes back to circles and added some additional support.  I very often use Sketchup to get an object's dimensions and adjust them.  Some, I simply recreate the part having the original side by side to my own.  In other cases, especially for complex objects, I copy a portion of the object and paste it into my own creation preserving the object's dimensions and shape.  In the case of the the external micro-SD reader, I imported the object in Sketchup, and customized it to my liking (without the hole for the rod).  Then I imported the customized creation into Meshmixer and repaired the object and exported it as a binary STL.  HPonstein's original STL file which I imported into Sketchup needed some repair otherwise it would not print correctly so it was necessary to leverage Meshmixer.  I'm an amateur, mind you.  I say that only to emphasize, no one should hesitate to jump in and try their hand at Sketchup, Meshmixer and other related applications.

author: Straeker

title: Electric lock pick gun
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Electric lock pick gun. This is a work in progress, the handle and motormount are separate, but I simply superglued them together once I had everything printed.

I have successfully used this on some simple locks, but I am no expert at using it. It likely has some major limitations compared to a professional electric lock pick gun, but still fun to build.

The cam gets super glued onto the motor shaft and due to it being off center, it creates the up and down ossilation motion of the pick.

The motor I used came from a remote control car that I had torn apart, but the size seemed pretty standard and could be found at most electronic stores. The button is from radioshack and the gun uses a 9v battery.

This does require a little soldering, post printing adjustements to make sure the pieces all run smoothly, and some superglue.

It's a little rough looking and is a work in progress, but I hope you enjoy.

Here's a video of it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=08IF598p2gI&feature=youtu.be

author: Justy_guy

title: Shock mount for Blue Snowball iCE Condenser Microphone

description.text:
UPDATE 26 Dec 2016: Uploaded counter-synced versions (NOTE: The the counter-synced clamp is not compatible with the normal inner ring and vise versa)
UPDATE 27 Dec 2016: Added the "Mini" version (NOTE: might require a counter weight)
UPDATE 28 Dec 2016: Added counter-synced "Mini" versions and updated the distance of the holes in the "Mini" version

I needed a shock mount for my mic, and i could find one so i made this one (follows the design principles of the official one.

You will need to design/find a way to mount it to a stand or a tripod, i left some some lower holes for that.

Print all the necessary parts (you only need one outer ring)

You will need to dismantle the tripod that came with the mic. ( or use a 5/8" screw if you can find imperial screws in your country)

  1. Assemble the outer ring (if you printed the modular outer ring)
  2. Use M3 x 20 screws (or equivalent metric) screw >ring>washer>nut>washer>nut in the inner and outer ring (as shown in the picture.
  3. Use an elastic band and string around the screws it both rings in a Zig-Zag pattern. (make sure you offset the inner and outer ring if you used the tripod mount option, also the band should be stiff to support the weight of the mic)
  4. Mount the outer ring any way you want.

The suction cup for my Garmin Dash Cam 20 does not like sticking to the windshield of my truck in the winter time. So made a mount to hand the GPS from the rear view mirror support in my Ford Super Duty truck.

Tried to make the part in one piece, but had a hard time trying to get it to print properly with support, so broke the part into two pieces and can print it without any support. Just need a 3mmx25mm machine screw and a 3mm nut. Hole for the nut is deep enough for a locking nut.
a bowser jr for YOUR 3d printer!!!

So, after searching thingiverse for a while, I couldnt find a hinge that suited my needs. Im making a printer enclosure for my TEVO tarantula and I needed small hinges for the plexiglass front door, but the local hardware store only has 1 size (too large) and they cost about 3-4 euros per pair! These ones cost me about 0.5 per pair on material!

So, after printing a couple of prototypes, I finally settled with these ones.
hinge_l is the loose half, so the one rotating around the axle.
hinge_t is the tight half, which 'holds' the axle. Keep in mind that the hole for the axle might be a little bit too tight or loose depending on your printer settings.

Note that the parts need to be rotated (the chamfered side is down) and I used supports for the one overhanging part.

For me, it works like a charm!

title: Traditional bushing 8x15x24mm (LM8UU) with grease trap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Traditional 8mm bushing with internal grease trap.

Summary: Don't use MoS2 grease for printed bushings, it's a fail. PTFE spray can oil works with PETG bushings if wiped dry after saturation. I have not tested silicon based or lithium based lubricants. I did look for graphite dry lubricant spray as a first choice but I did not find any in my vicinity so I chose PTFE spray can oil instead and as previously stated it seems to work if wiped dry after saturation.

My first attemp to grease the Y-axis I used MoS2 dark grey grease, it worked sufficient for the linear ball bearings. When I used MoS2 dark grey grease to my printed bushings it did not work at all, tried it with PLA-bushings and PETG-bushings, they all seemed to work at first, but after one day or less they started to get to snug on the rods, they got stuck and the stepper motor struggeled with resistanse to move. NO GO for MoS2 grease and printed bushings!

I printed a new batch of PETG bushings and tried them with sprayed PTFE oil (tens of thusands of PFTE balls per mm2, micro gap fillers), I used a threaded rod to grind the bushings to tolerance, moving the bushing back and forth along the threaded rod slowly rotating them both while applying pressure (using an 8mm drill bit might work better). Grind a while and the check the bushing against the bearing rod, grind a bit more etc. until satisfied with the tolerance. I found it to be sufficient if the bushing slides easy along the rod while dry, but sticking while wet with PTFE spray can oil. I grind the bushings until they just slide easy by them selves by gravity on the rods but sticks to the rod when saturated with PTFE oil. When satisfied with tolerance I saturated both the rods and the bushings with PTFE spray can oil, moved the bushings along the rods for a while and then thouroghly wiped them all dry with toilet paper, inside of bushings as well as whole of the rods. When saturated the bushings does not fall by gravity on the rods, they are sucked by viscosity to the rods, but when wiped clean they fall easy and fast along the rods!

Lesson1: MoS2 dark gray grease works with linear ball bearings if applied inside the bearings. The linear ball bearings runs quiet and smooth with MoS2 dark gray grease (quality of bearings may vary).
Lesson2: MoS2 grease does not work at all for printed bushings, neither PLA or PETG! At least not with fine tolerances between the rod and bushing.
Lesson3: PLA might be partially dissolved by MoS2 and refined oils, I don't know, but it could be why the smoothness feels ok the first day but not the next day. PETG are resistant to oils and greases, or so they say.
Lesson4: PTFE spray can oil works with PETG bushings if you saturate the inside of the bushings and on the rods with PTFE oil, move them back and forth rapidly by hand for a while and when done wipe them completely dry inside and out. Important to understand that if wet by oil (or grease) the bushings sticks to the rod by viscosity and boundary layer adhesion. Wipe everything dry using fresh toilet paper after saturated with PTFE spray can oil, remount and realign everything carefully and you should end up with a quiet linear PETG bushing heatbed. I did.

From my, trial and error, pratical experience.
/peen333
